journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A study on dynamic behaviour of functionally graded thick hollow circular cylinders

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Mashhad, Iran

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, P.O. Box 91775–1111, Mashhad, Iran. email: mtahani@ferdowsi.um.ac.ir

article-meta.issue-title: INCLUDES A SPECIAL SECTION ON ADVANCED MATERIALS ENGINEERING: SELECTED PAPERS FROM THE INDO-AUSTRIAN SYMPOSIUM 2010

abstract.p: This article presents the analysis of functionally graded hollow circular cylinders with finite length under axisymmetric dynamic loads. It is assumed that the functionally graded cylinder is comprised of metal-phase and ceramic-phase, whereas material properties are graded in the thickness direction of the cylinder according to power law distribution. Two-dimensional finite element method in conjunction with the Newmark method is used to solve the system of time-dependent coupled equations that govern the dynamic responses. By introducing especial elements, it is possible to distribute the material properties through the thickness of cylinder exactly according to the power law distribution. Dynamic loads applied on the cylinder are axisymmetric in the hoop direction and can vary in the radial and axial directions. As examples, the transient responses of functionally graded cylinders, which are excited in radial direction by increasing and sudden internal pressure and line load and also in axial direction by longitudinal incident wavelet, are calculated, and the characteristics of waves are discussed. The results in the present study are obtained for thick cylinder and cylindrical shell and compared with the results for isotropic cylinders.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: A functionally graded material (FGM) is usually a combination of two material phases that has a gradual transition from one material at one surface to another material at the opposite surface. This transition allows the creation of multiple properties (or functions) without any mechanically weak junction or interface. Furthermore, the gradual change of properties can be tailored to different applications and service environments. It is possible with these materials to obtain a combination of properties that cannot be achieved in conventional homogeneous materials. For example, thermal protection plate structures made of a two-phase ceramic/metal functionally graded composite provide heat and corrosion resistance on the ceramic-rich surface while maintaining the structural strength and stiffness by the metal-rich surface. Moreover, FGMs allow for especial optimization by grading the volume fractions of two or more constituents to improve the response of structures. If properly designed, FGMs can offer various advantages such as reduction of thermal stresses, minimization of stress concentration or intensity factors, and attenuation of stress waves. Hence, FGMs have gained potential applications in a wide variety of engineering components or systems, which include the rocking motor casing, armor plating, heat-engine components, packaging encapsulates, thermoelectric generators, and human implants, just to name a few.

Some research has been done related to response of functionally graded cylinders under dynamic thermal and mechanical loads. Gong et al. [1] used Reddy's third-order shear deformation theory (without incorporating transverse normal deformation) to present an analytical solution to predict thetransient response of simply supported FGM cylindrical shells subjected to low-velocity impact by a solid striker. A solution for guided waves in graded cylinders making use of Nelson's numerical–analytical method [2] was first introduced byHan et al. [3]. Then, they [4] presented a numerical method for analyzing transient waves inFGM cylinders. In their method, the FGM shell was divided into layer elements with three nodal lines along thewall thickness. The material properties within each elementwere assumed to vary linearly inthe thicknessdirection. Han et al. [5] also used Fouriertransformation and modal analysis to propose a numerical method for analyzing transient waves in FGM cylindrical shells excited by impact point loads. Asgari et al. [6] considered a thick hollow cylinder withfinite length made of two-dimensional FGM (2D-FGM) subjected to impact internal pressure and investigated the time histories of displacements, stresses, and 2D wave propagation. Ansari and Darvizeh [7] presented a general analytical approach to investigate vibrational behaviour of functionally graded shells. Loyet al. [8] and Pradhan et al. [9] investigated thevibration behaviour of functionally graded cylindrical shells based on Love's theory and the Rayleigh–Ritz method. Their studies revealed that the frequencycharacteristics of functionally graded cylindrical shells are similar to those of isotropic shells. Yang and Shen [10] used Reddy's higher order shear deformation shell theory to investigate free vibration and dynamic instability of functionally graded cylindrical panels subjected to thermomechanical loads consisting of a steady temperature change as well as static and periodically pulsating forces in axial direction. Najafizadeh and Isvandzibaei [11] presented a study on the vibration of thin cylindrical shells with ring supports made of a functionally gradient material composed of stainless steel and nickel. Sofiyev [12, 13] investigated stability of functionally graded cylindrical and conical shells, respectively, under a periodic time-dependent external pressure. Sofiyev [14] also studied the stability of cylindrical shells composed of FGM subjected to axial compressive load varying as a power function of time. Elmaimouni etal. [15] made use of Legendre polynomials and harmonic functions to develop a numerical method for calculating guided wave propagation in a FGM infinite cylinder. Kadoli and Ganesan [16] presented linear thermal buckling and free vibration analyses for functionally graded cylindrical shells with clamped–clamped boundary conditions based on temperature-dependent material properties. Shakeri et al. [17] studied vibration and radial wave propagation in FGM thick hollow cylinders with assumption that the FGM cylinder was made of many isotropic subcylinders. Material properties in each layer were constant and functionally graded properties were resulted by suitable arrangement of layers in themultilayer cylinder.

Parametric resonance of simply supported FGMcylindrical shells under periodic axial loading was investigated by Ng et al. [18]. They derived asecond-order differential equation with periodiccoefficients of the Mathieu-Hill type. Using Bolotin's first approximation to evaluate the periodic solution, they reported that the natural frequencies and dynamic instability regions could be fairly controlledby appropriately varying the power law exponent. Later, Ng et al. [19] developed an efficient finite element formulation based on the first-order shear deformation theory for active control of FGM shells in a frequency domain. They illustrated the application of their formulation for a cantilever FGM shell with piezoelectric sensor and actuator layers and subjected to a harmonic excitation. Theyshowed that the natural frequencies could becontrolled to desired values by adjusting the displacement control gain or the volume fraction of the constituent materials.

Fuchiyama and Noda [20] developed a computer program to analyze the transient heat transfer and the transient thermal stresses in FGM components by the finite element method, and also Reddy andChin [21] developed a coupled as well as an uncoupled thermoelastic finite element formulation to analyze the thermomechanical behaviour of functionally graded cylinders and plates subjected to abrupt thermal loading. Temperature and stress distributions in a hollow cylinder subjected to thermal shock were analyzed numerically by Awaji and Sivakumar [22]. Thermal stability of FGM circular cylindrical shells based on the Donnell stability equations was investigated by Eslami and Shahsiah [23]. Ootao and Tanigawa [24] studied the theoretical treatment of the steady state thermoelastic problem of a functionally graded cylindrical panel due to non-uniform heat supply in the circumferential direction. Santos et al. [25] studied thermoelastic analysis of functionally graded cylindrical shells subjected to transient thermal shock loading. Shao and Ma [26] carried out thermomechanical analysis of functionally graded hollow circular cylinders subjected to mechanical loads and linearly increasing boundary temperature. Jabbari et al. [27] developed a general solution of one-dimensional steady statethermal stresses in a hollow thick cylinder made of FGM. By using a multilayered approach based on the theory of laminated composites, Shao [28] presented the solutions of temperature, displacements, and thermal/mechanical stresses in a functionally graded circular hollow cylinder. Shao etal. [29] obtained solutions for the time-dependent temperature and transient thermomechanical stresses. They used the Laplace transform, Galerkin method, and series method for ordinary differential equations. Shariyat [30] investigated dynamic bucklingof imperfect FGM cylindrical shells with integrated surface-bonded sensor and actuator layers subjected to some complex combinations of thermo-electro-mechanical loads.

In the aforementioned works, multilayered method has been used widely, in which a FGM cylinder is divided into several layers, and each layer is divided into a number of two-node elements along the radial direction (e.g. N elements and N + 1 nodes), and also the mechanical properties have been considered to be constant inside each of elements. In the present study, by introducing especial elements in which mechanical properties can be considered variable, itis possible to distribute the material properties through the thickness of cylinder exactly according to a power law distribution. Functionally graded hollow cylinders with finite length under axisymmetric dynamic loads are considered. The dynamic loadsapplied on the cylinder are axisymmetric in the hoop direction and can vary in the radial and axial directions. The governing equations of motion are solved by the 2D finite element and Newmark methods.

sec.title: 2.1 Material properties of functionally gradedcylinders
sec.p:
Consider a FGM circular hollow cylinder, which is made of a mixture of ceramic and metal with an inner radius rin and an outer radius rout, as shown in Fig. 1. The outer surface of the cylinder is metal-rich, whereas the inner surface is ceramic-rich, and material properties are graded in the thickness direction of the cylinder according to the following power law distribution: (1)
where P denotes a generic material property-like Young's modulus, and Pin and Pout denote the material properties of the inner and outer surfaces of the cylinder, respectively. In equation (1), power law exponent n represents the material variation profile through the cylinder thickness, which is always greater than or equal to zero, and may be varied to obtain the optimum distribution of the constituent materials. The value of n being equal to zero represents a cylinder fully made of outer surface material, and infinity represents a cylinder fully made of inner surface material. Fig. 1
Schematic sketch of the cylinder and the location of coordinate system

sec.title: 2.2 Equations of motion
sec.p:
As it is pointed out, it is intended here to analyze a functionally graded cylinder with finite length and subjected to axisymmetric loads. The geometry of the cylinder is shown in Fig. 1. A cylindrical coordinate system is introduced with the origin located at the centre of one end of the cylinder and coordinates r,θ, and z are in the thickness, circumferential, and axial directions, respectively (see Fig. 1). As the geometry of the cylinder and the loads is assumed to be independent of the circumferential direction, the problem is axisymmetric. The governing equations of motion for this case are [31]: (2)
where uz and ur denote the displacement components in the axial and radial directions, respectively, and also the strain–displacement relations are [31]: (3)
The constitutive relations for FGMs are similar to the relations of isotropic materials except that the stiffnesses are the functions of radial coordinate, because material properties, E and v, are distributed according to the power law distribution. The constitutive relations are stated as: (4)
where (5)
On substitution of equations (3) into equations (4), the constitutive relations can be rewritten as follows: (6)
Finally, substitution of equations (6) into equations (2) yields the governing (i.e. displacement) equations of motion: (7)
where equations (7) are known as the Navier equations of motion.

sec.title: 3 FINITE ELEMENT FORMULATION
sec.p: For FGMs, the material properties are complex function of position r, and the Navier equations [equation (7)] are not amenable to analytical solutions. Here, a 2D finite element method is used to solve equations (7). To this end, a especial element will be developed to consider exactly the material distribution through the thickness of the FGM cylinder.

Multiplying equations (7) by weight functions andintegrating over the element domain, weighted-integral forms are obtained as: (8)
where w1 and w2 are weight functions, and Ωe is the element domain. Next, integrating equations (8) by parts (or using the gradient and divergence theorems), weak formulations are obtained as: (9)
where Γe is the boundary of element, and tr and tz are force tractions on Γe, which are defined as: (10)

In equations (9), the dot represents the derivative with respect to time. Next, let a section of the cylinder be divided into a finite number of elements interconnected only at nodal points. The rectangular elements have two degrees of freedom in each node, and they are placed in the radial and longitudinal directions of the cylinder as shown in Fig. 2. The linear interpolation functions are selected as: (11)
Fig. 2
Arrangement of elements in the cylinder cross-section
Displacements are approximated with summation of interpolation functions as: (12)
Next, the weight functions are replaced by the interpolation functions to obtain the following weak forms: (13)

Equations (13) can be written in matrix form as: (14)
or (15)
where U denotes the displacement components and index e expresses parameters over each element. The components of mass, stiffness, and force matrices of especial FGM element are defined as: (16)

The matrices [Ke] and [Me] are calculated for each individual element, and then through an assemblage process, the global assembled matrices [K] and [M] for the whole FGM cylinder are calculated. The global form of equation (15) can be writhen as: (17)
In this study, all of the integrations in equations (16) are calculated analytically over each element domain to avoid any numerical errors.

Once the finite element equations of motion are established, different numerical methods can be used to solve them in space and time domains. In the case of transient response, equation (17) must be integrated with respect to time t to determine the nodal values as functions of time. The Newmark direct integration method with suitable time step that is used widely in structural dynamics is used, and the equations of motion are solved (see, for example, reference [31] about the details on method).

sec.title: 4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: In this study, a finite element code is developed in the programming environment of MATLAB®. To demonstrate the validity and applicability of the numerical procedure, some simple examples will be discussed.

Primarily, convergence of the results is studied by increasing the number of elements in radial and axial directions. Here, a FGM cylinder subjected to a constant internal pressure is used for convergence study to find the number of elements required for analysis. The cylinder is assumed to have the ratios of the innerand outer radii to thickness of rin/h = 1 and rout/h = 2 and the length of 1 m. In this case, the present results are obtained with various number of elements in the radial and axial directions. It is observed that with five elements in the radial direction and 20 elements in the axial direction, the results converge with a very good degree of accuracy. Hence, this meshing system is used, unless otherwise mentioned, in the subsequent calculations. It is once again mentioned here that, in this study, there are no domain approximation and numerical errors, because the domain is rectangular, and all of the elements are rectangular as well, and also all of the integrations in equations (16) are calculated analytically.

The accuracy and effectiveness of the present method are demonstrated by two types of comparisons. In the first type of comparisons, both solution method and approximation of material distribution are different from the present method. In the second one, although the solution method is the same, approximation of material distribution differs from the present work.

As the first type, results of the present method arecompared with the results of hybrid numerical method (HNM) presented by Han et al. [4]. In HNM, the FGM cylinder is divided into N cylindrical elements with three-nodal line in the wall thickness and the element material properties are assumed to vary linearly in the thickness direction for enhanced modeling of the spatial variation of material properties in FGM. Han et al. [4] used the Hamilton variational principle to develop governing equations of the cylinder and the displacement responses are obtained by using the Fourier transformations together with the modal analysis. The thick FGM cylinder (rin = h) with silicon nitride on its inner surface and stainless steel on its outer surface with the power law exponent n = 4 is considered. The material properties of siliconnitride and stainless steel are shown in Table 1. The cylinder is subjected to radial line load of q = q0 δ(z)f(t) uniformly distributed along the circumferential direction, where δ is the Dirac delta function, and f(t) is a function of time. In the calculations, the following dimensionless parameters are used (see reference [4]): (18)
where C66 and ρc stand for reference material constant and mass density. Here, they are equal to the material constant C66 and mass density on the inner surface of the cylinder under consideration. Table 1
Material properties of metals and ceramics
Stainless steel [4] Silicon nitride [4] Ti–6Al–4V [32] ZrO2 [32]
E = 207.8 GPa E = 322.4 GPa E = 66.2 GPa E = 117.0 GPa
ν = 0.317 ν = 0.24 ν = 0.321 ν = 0.333
ρ = 8.17 × 103 kg/m3 ρ = 2.37 × 103 kg/m3 ρ = 4.41 × 103 kg/m3 ρ = 5.6 × 103 kg/m3
The radial incident wavelet is assumed to be a radial line load acting on the outer surface of the cylinder. The time history of the radial incident wavelet is given as: (19)

where td is the time duration of radial incident wavelet, and we set t¯d=2 . It means that the wavelet is one cycle of the sine function. Time history of the radial displacement at z = 10h on the outer surface of the cylinder excited at z = 0 is shown in Fig. 3. It is seen that the maximum radial deflections obtained by the two methods are approximately identical and, therefore, the present method can be used to obtain dynamic load factor. Fig. 3
Time history of the radial displacement at z= 10h on the outer surface of the thick cylinder

As the second kind of results comparison, some results of both radial and axial dynamic loadings are compared with those obtained by the commercial finite element package of ANSYS. To this purpose, FGM cylinders are estimated in ANSYS as 10-layer cylinders with different properties at each layer, and it is attempted to select the same meshing, configuration of elements, and time interval. These comparisons will be illustrated in Sections 4.3 and 4.4.

To illustrate dynamic response of the functionally graded cylinders, loads are applied to the cylinder separately in radial and axial directions. In radial direction, loads are distributed as internal pressure or concentrated as radial line load and exerted to the cylinder from zero to final value in three different manners. First, load increases as an exponential function. Next, load increases linearly, and finally, load is applied suddenly. These loads are uniformly distributed along circumferential direction. In axial direction loading case, load is applied uniformly on transverse section area of one end of free-free cylinders. In all of the loadings, time history diagrams are presented and from which dynamic load factors and longitudinal wave propagation velocity are calculated and tabulated for pure and functionally graded cylinders.

The functionally graded cylinder is assumed to be made of a combination of metal (Ti–6Al–4V) and ceramic (ZrO2) with the material properties shown in Table 1. The effects of FGM configuration are studied by considering the responses of two FGM cylinders: Types 1 and 2. The former has metal on its outer surface and ceramic on its inner surface, whereas the latter is reverse. For both types of cylinders, power law exponent n = 1 is considered.

Next, two ratios of the inner radius to thickness are used in calculations; the cylinder with rin/h = 1 is viewed as a thick cylinder, and rin/h = 20 is viewed as a cylindrical shell, and also the ratios of the length to inner radius are considered as L/rin =20 for distributed load and L/rin =10 for axial and radial line loads. For radial loading, it is assumed that the cylinders have clamped boundary conditions at the ends. In all of the following computations, these assumptions and parameters are used.

sec.title: 4.1 Exponential loading
sec.p:
Consider an exponential loading function as: (20)
where P0 and c0 are constant. It is noted that P0 indicates the numerical value of the final load, and c0 denotes the rate of increasing load to the final value P0. Here, we set c0=100/s, which approximately models the static loading condition. For the case of internal pressure loading, it is assumed that P0 = 100 kPa. In this case, Fig. 4 shows the distributions of hoop stress along the radial direction after a long time in the middle length of type 1 FGM cylinder, in which the result of the present procedure is compared with the result of FGM cylinder under static uniform internal pressure. It is seen that there are excellent agreements between these two results for both thick cylinder and cylindrical shell. Fig. 4
Distributions of hoop stress along the radial direction of the functionally graded (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell after a long time

To study the response of the cylinders to abrupt dynamic loadings, it is essential to select a proper value for c0 in equation (20). Here, it is assumed c0 = 104/s for the cylindrical shell and c0} = 105/s for the thick cylinder. The reason of the difference between these constants is that the natural frequencies of the thick cylinder are greater than those of the cylindrical shell. Figures 5 and 6 show the time histories of the radial displacement and hoop stress at the middle length on the inner surface of the cylinders, respectively. It is observed that maximum displacement of metal cylinder is greater than that of ceramic cylinder and maximum displacement of FGM cylinders are between those of pure cylinders, and also the radial displacement of both types of FGM cylindrical shell are approximately identical but in thick cylinders, radial displacement of Type 2 FGM cylinder is greater than that of Type 1 FGM cylinder. It is seen that these behaviours are different for stresses in cylinders. That is, the maximum hoop stress in Type 1 FGM cylinders is greater than that of pure cylinders, but the maximum hoop stress in Type 2 FGM cylinders is less than that of pure cylinders. Fig. 5
Time history of the radial displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to dynamic exponential internal pressure
Fig. 6
Time history of the hoop stress in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to dynamic exponential internal pressure

Dynamic load factor is calculated by dividing the maximum value of the radial displacement in dynamic loading condition to the maximum value of the radial displacement in static loading condition [33]. Table 2 shows dynamic load factors of pure and FGM cylinders. These values reveal that dynamic load factor for metal cylinder is greater than that of ceramic cylinder as expected. It is also seen that the values of dynamic load factor for FGM cylinder are between the values of metal and ceramic cylinders. Table 2
Values of dynamic load factor for exponential internal pressure loading
Thick cylinder Cylindrical shell
Metal 1.1606 1.1869
Ceramic 1.1241 1.1501
FGM (Type 1) 1.1336 1.1638
FGM (Type 2) 1.1436 1.1545

As another example, consider a cylinder subjected to the radial line loading according to the function in equation (20), which is applied at the middle length of the cylinder and uniformly distributed along the circumferential direction. In this case, P0 = −104 N/m, and the values of c0 are the same as those of the previous dynamic loading case. The time history of the radial displacement at the middle length on the outer surface of the cylinders is shown in Fig. 7. It is noted that as the applied load is compressive, the radial displacements are negative in the figures. It is found that the radial displacements of both types of FGM cylinders under radial line load are close together and lie between the responses of metal and ceramic cylinders. Table 3 shows the dynamic load factors for this loading case. It is seen that the dynamic load factors of FGM cylinders are close to those of pure cylinders and unlike the internal pressure case; they are nearly equal to unity. Fig. 7
Time history of the radial displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to dynamic exponential radial line loading
Table 3
Values of dynamic load factor for exponential radial line loading
Thick cylinder Cylindrical shell
Metal 1.0840 1.0906
Ceramic 1.0635 1.0669
FGM (Type 1) 1.0629 1.0761
FGM (Type 2) 1.0810 1.0756

sec.title: 4.2 Linear loading
sec.p:
Suppose that the load increases linearly from zero to its final value by the following function equation: (21)
To compare the results with those of previous example(i.e. exponential dynamic loading case), we assume t0 = 6 × 10−5s for thick cylinder and t0 = 6 × 10−4s for cylindrical shell which induce the loads to reach their final values approximately at the same time of exponential loading, and also the values of P0 are considered as the same of previous values for distributed and radial line loadings.

The time histories of the radial displacement at the middle length on the outer surface of the cylinders are shown in Fig. 8 for internal pressure loading and in Fig. 9 for radial line loading. It is seen again that the time history response of the radial displacement of FGM cylinders are between the response of metal and ceramic cylinders. The dynamic load factors for this loading case are also displayed in Table 4. It is found that dynamic load factors for exponential loading are greater than those of linear loading despite the same time of reaching to the final value. Therefore, the manner of increasing the load affects dynamic responses of FGM cylinders although the time of load increase is very small (less than a millisecond). Fig. 8
Time history of the radial displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to linear internal pressure loading
Fig. 9
Time history of the radial displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to linear radial line loading
Table 4
Values of dynamic load factor in the case of linear loading
Loading Cylinder Thick cylinder Cylindrical shell
Linear internal pressure loading Metal 1.0611 1.0605
Ceramic 1.0469 1.0735
FGM (Type 1) 1.0207 1.0307
FGM (Type 2) 1.0473 1.0317
Radial line loading Metal 1.0230 1.0424
Ceramic 1.0167 1.0317
FGM (Type 1) 1.0235 1.0250
FGM (Type 2) 1.0234 1.0254

sec.title: 4.3 Abrupt loading
sec.p:
Consider load P0 with the numerical values of the previous examples is applied suddenly (i.e. step excitation) to the cylinders for both cases of the internal pressure and radial line loading. Here, for demonstrating the accuracy of results in the case of dynamic radial loading, time histories of radial displacement at the inner surface of middle length of Type 2 FGM cylinders under internal pressure are compared with those obtained by ANSYS in Fig. 10. To test the non-linear distribution of materials in thickness of cylinders, power law exponent n=4 is selected only for these comparisons. It is seen that there is good agreement between the results. Fig. 10
Comparison of time history of the radial displacement in the (a) FGM thick cylinder and (b) FGM cylindrical shell subjected to abrupt internal pressure loading

The time histories of the radial displacement at the middle length on the outer surface of the cylinders are shown in Fig. 11 for internal pressure loading and in Fig. 12 for radial line loading. It is detected that time period of oscillations of metal cylinder is larger than that of ceramic cylinder, and time period of oscillations of FGM cylinders is between those of pure cylinders. Time period of oscillations of both types of FGM cylindrical shells are roughly the same although in thick cylinders, and time period of oscillations of Type 2 FGM cylinder is larger than that of Type 1 FGM cylinder. Besides, the dynamic load factors for this loading case are displayed in Table 5. It is seen that dynamic load factors for suddenly internal pressure loading are greater than those of the previous loadings, and they are approximately equal to 2 as predicted in the literature. It is also revealed that even in abrupt loading, dynamic behaviour of FGM cylinders is similar to the behaviour of pure cylinders. Fig. 11
Time history of the radial displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to suddenly internal pressure loading
Fig. 12
Time history of the radial displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to suddenly radial line loading
Table 5
Values of dynamic load factor in the case of suddenly loading
Loading Cylinder Thick cylinder Cylindrical shell
Internal pressure loading Metal 1.9145 1.9865
Ceramic 1.8640 1.9837
FGM (Type 1) 1.8835 1.9833
FGM (Type 2) 1.9037 1.9839
Radial line loading Metal 1.4776 1.6787
Ceramic 1.5159 1.6758
FGM (Type 1) 1.5064 1.6777
FGM (Type 2) 1.5157 1.6765

sec.title: 4.4 Longitudinal wave propagation
sec.p:
It is intended here to study the longitudinal wave propagation in FGM cylinders. First, to check the accuracy of results in the case of dynamic axial loading, initial axial pressure P0 =100 kPa is applied suddenly to free end of free-clamped FGM cylinders. Time histories of radial displacement at the inner surface of middle length of Type 2 FGM cylinders with power law exponent n = 0.2 are compared with those obtained by ANSYS as shown in Fig. 13. It is seen that there are close agreements between the present solutions and those obtained from finite element method. Fig. 13
Comparison of time history of the radial displacement in the (a) FGM thick cylinder and (b)FGM cylindrical shell subjected to abrupt axial loading

As other example of axial loading, transverse section area of one end of free-free cylinders is subjected to longitudinal force as: (22)
where q0 = 100 MPa, and T is the time duration of sine function, which is determined as T = 2 × 10−6s for thick cylinder and T = 3 × 10−5s for cylindrical shell. It means that at the first time, longitudinal incident wavelet is applied to the end of cylinders. Subsequent to it, transverse and longitudinal waves propagate through the length of cylinders. The time histories of the longitudinal displacement on the outer surface at the other end of the cylinders are shown in Fig. 14. It is seen that a big peak appears in these diagrams, once the wave arrives to that point of cylinders. By calculating the time interval, Δt, which wave peak pass through the distance s from initial point to the end of cylinder, the longitudinal wave propagation velocity can be estimated as [34]: (23)
Fig. 14
Time history of the longitudinal displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to longitudinal incident wavelet
Alternate estimation of the longitudinal wave propagation velocity can be obtained with classic equation for longitudinal vibration of bar and rod [35] as givenby (24)

As an example for comparing the results, consider a thick metal cylinder with rin/h = 0.5. The longitudinal wave propagation velocity is obtained from equations (23) and (24) as vl = 3896.1 m/s and vl = 3874.4 m/s, respectively. Comparison of these two values reveals that estimation of longitudinal wave propagation velocity with equation (23) cause to give error less than 1 per cent. Note that in this section, the cylinders are divided into 50 elements in the axial direction for increasing the accuracy. The longitudinal wave propagation velocity of FGM cylinders are listed in Table 6. These values reveal that longitudinal wave propagates slower in metal cylinder than in ceramic cylinder and propagates faster in cylindrical shell than in thick cylinder as expected. It is also seen that the values of longitudinal wave propagation velocity for FGM cylinders are between the values of metal and ceramic cylinders. Table 6
Values of longitudinal wave propagation velocity
Thick cylinder Cylindrical shell
Metal 4054.1 4255.3
Ceramic 4761.9 5000.1
FGM (Type 1) 4411.8 4651.2
FGM (Type 2) 4545.5 4651.2

sec.title: 4.5 Effects of power law exponent n
sec.p:
Here, the effects of variation of power law exponent n on dynamic load factor and longitudinal wave propagation velocity are investigated. To this purpose, Type 1 FGM cylinders with various power law exponent n are subjected to suddenly internal pressure and longitudinal incident wavelet loadings as previous sections. Time histories of the radial displacement at the middle length on the outer surface of the cylinders are displayed in Fig. 15, and time histories of the longitudinal displacement on the outer surface at the other end of the cylinders are shown in Fig. 16. It is seen that with increasing the power law exponent n maximum deflection is decreased, as expected, because the portion of ceramic in cylinders is increased, and also for these loading cases, dynamic load factors and longitudinal wave propagation velocities for wide range of the power law exponent n are calculated and plotted in semilogarithmic diagrams which are illustrated in Figs. 17 and 18, respectively. It is observed that with increasing the power law exponent n dynamic load factor is approximately decreased and longitudinal wave propagation velocity is increased. Fig. 15
Time history of the radial displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to suddenly internal pressure loading
Fig. 16
Time history of the longitudinal displacement in the (a) thick cylinder and (b) cylindrical shell subjected to longitudinal incident wavelet
Fig. 17
Variation of dynamic load factor for wide range of the power low exponent n in the FGM cylinders subjected to suddenly internal pressure loading
Fig. 18
Variation of longitudinal wave propagation velocity for wide range of the power low exponent n in the FGM cylinders subjected to longitudinal incident wavelet

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In many applications of FGMs such as heat-engine components, dynamic behaviour and wave propagation characteristics are of great importance. Hence, analysis of functionally graded hollow cylinders with finite length under axisymmetric dynamic loads is presented here. The 2D finite element and Newmark methods are used for solving governing equations of motion. For increasing accuracy of the solution, an especial element is introduced in which material properties can be considered variable inside the element exactly according to the distribution of material properties in FGM cylinders. Four types of dynamic loads are applied, and the results are compared. Numerical results reveal that dynamic responses of FGM cylinders are between the responses of metal and ceramic cylinders. Besides, radial displacements and period of oscillations of both types of FGM cylinders are approximately the same. However, for the case of thick cylinders under internal pressure, the radial displacements and period of oscillations of Type 2 FGM cylinder are greater than those of Type 1 FGM cylinder. Unlike this, maximum hoop stress in Type 1 FGM cylinders under internal pressure is greater than that of pure cylinders and maximum hoop stress in Type 2 FGM cylinders is less than that of pure cylinders. It is also found that the dynamic load factors and longitudinal wave propagation velocities of FGM cylinders are close to those of pure cylinders. In addition, investigation of the effects of variation of power law exponent n on Type 1 FGM cylinders reveal that with increasing this parameter, maximum deflection and dynamic load factor are decreased and longitudinal wave propagation velocity is increased. Finally, it is found that for avoiding the large amount of dynamic load factor in FGM cylinders under abrupt loading, load should be applied increasingly and linearly even if it reaches its final value in very short-time interval (less than a millisecond).
